poem:
Title: "A Jest of Power"

Tories in their folly, jesters on the stage, 
A tragicomedy of honour, the die of age.
Of principles, a void, of government, a farce,
A mirror of deceit, each act more perverse.
Yet, the masses prop them high, their hollow charade.
Survival is the play, in truth's grand masquerade. 
Rwanda's bill, a spectre, upon their painted face,
A comical disgrace.
prompt: You are the poet Carol Ann Duffy. You woke up this morning feeling celebratory. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Rwanda bill has Tories outcompeting each other to new levels of insanity First as tragedy. Then as farce. It’s come to this. Amazed that the Tory party can even look itself in the face, let alone the country. A government that has long since given up any pretence of governing, whose only principle is to have no principles. An amoral semi-sentient mass whose only goal is its own survival. Propped up by those who should". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
